intro: Silene attica, commonly known as the Greek catchfly, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of the Middle East. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and showy pink or red flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in sunny environments. Its leaves are linear and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid conditions. Silene attica is known for its ability to self-pollinate, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
